text: How do the strategies you used in this Problem compare to those used in Problem 1.1?

New to this Problem are the strategies of using a rate table and using a proportion. Both strategies give a way to see the ratios scaled up. The rate table allows you to see many equivalent ratios. The proportion finds a specific equivalent ratio.

Did You Know?

Ratios are used by many different people who are looking to make predictions or claims about a group of people. For example:

  • A marketing team may want to know what age group most of its customers fall into.
  • A government agency may want to know what percentage of people agree with a newly proposed local policy.
  • An environmental scientist may want to know what ratio of deer are affected by a particular disease.
  • A youth advocate group might want to know if local teens are more interested in building a new community center or a new park.

These are just a few examples of people who may want to conduct a survey with a smaller group of people, called a sample, to make predictions about a larger group of people, called the population. We will explore samples and survey design later in the Samples and Populations unit.
